nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: The campus food bank operates from a converted store room near the mosque. Inside, shelves are stacked with donated groceries, and students sort items into boxes.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Abang Ibrahim, the food bank coordinator. He's been running this for 3 years, entirely volunteer-based.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: A senior student labeling boxes. His shirt says 'APU Volunteer Corps'.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Shelves filled with rice, instant noodles, canned food, and basic necessities. Everything is organized by expiry date.

nodes.speaker: Abang Ibrahim
nodes.text: Assalamualaikum! You must be the new volunteer from Prof Riza's class. Welcome to Dewan Makan!

nodes.speaker: Abang Ibrahim
nodes.text: We collect surplus food from donations, then distribute to students yang memerlukan. Every week, we help around 50 students.

nodes.speaker: Abang Ibrahim
nodes.text: Today we're packing care packages. Rice, milo, instant noodles, eggs, the basics. Can you help sort and pack? It's simple but meaningful work.

choices.text: Of course, Abang. Show me what to do.
I'll try lah, but I'm not sure how much help I can be.
Actually I thought I'd just observe first. Not ready to commit yet.

nodes.speaker: Abang Ibrahim
nodes.text: Alhamdulillah! That's the spirit. Every pair of hands makes a difference. Come, I show you the system.

nodes.speaker: Abang Ibrahim
nodes.text: Don't worry, everyone starts somewhere. Just follow Hafiz there, he'll guide you. You'll get the hang of it quickly.

nodes.speaker: Abang Ibrahim
nodes.text: Hmm, okay. You can watch first lah. But honestly, the best way to understand is to just try. No pressure though.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: For the next hour, you either help sort donations...or observe how volunteers work together.

nodes.speaker: Hafiz
nodes.text: Not bad for first time! You know, I started just like you. Came once to fill my co-curricular hours. Now I'm here every week.

choices.text: What made you keep coming back?
How many hours you get for this?

nodes.speaker: Hafiz
nodes.text: I met a student once who said this was his only proper meal that week. Changed everything for me. Suddenly it wasn't about hours anymore. You don`t always see who you`re helping...but they`re around us every day.

nodes.speaker: Hafiz
nodes.text: Haha, I knew you'd ask. 2 hours per session. But honestly ah, after a while you stop counting. The experience is worth more.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: Objective completed: Experience hands-on volunteering at the campus food bank. (SDG 2: Zero Hunger)

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Later that afternoon, outside the Student Union building, a small SDG awareness booth has been set up. Colorful banners flutter in the breeze, and students mill about curiously. The images from the food bank linger in your mind as you walk across campus.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: April from the Environmental Club is setting up a station for sustainability activities. She's been organizing events like this since Year 1.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Matthew, an international student from Indonesia, is setting up interactive demos to teach practical sustainability hacks.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: A small group of students are learning to make enzyme cleaner from fruit peels. Practical sustainability in action.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: A brave squirrel eyes the free snacks at the booth. Even wildlife seems curious about sustainability.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Hey! We’re setting up some small sustainability stuff today. Nothing too heavy — just things students actually do day to day. If you’ve got a few minutes, you can check it out.

choices.text: Sure! I just came from the food bank, so I’m really eager.
Interesting, but I need to rush for class. Maybe next time?
Nah, I don’t think this environmental stuff is for me.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Nice. Since you were just at the food bank, this one might hit a bit closer. We’re showing how food scraps and leftovers can be handled better instead of just throwing everything away. Let’s start with making enzyme cleaner from food scraps. How should we start preparing the orange peels for the mix?

choices.text: Peel the oranges carefully to avoid the white pith
Throw everything in the blender
Skip the prep and just add sugar and water

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Exactly! Removing the pith prevents bitterness and ensures the cleaner is effective. Small careful actions like this reduce chemical waste in your home.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Hmm...blending everything may work, but the cleaner won’t be as effective. Still, you’re learning how little details matter in sustainable practices.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: Skipping preparation will reduce effectiveness. But even trying teaches you that sustainable actions need some care and attention.

nodes.speaker: April
nodes.text: No worries lah. Even just seeing it once helps. You’ll start noticing these things around campus after a while. Take this pamphlet and follow us on Insta @APU_alamhijau. Even small awareness matters.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Hey. I help out here because back home, food waste and pollution are...bad. When I came here, I realised we still waste a lot, just less visibly.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Since you were helping at the food bank, let’s explore food waste reduction. Small actions here can make a big difference. Ready to try?

choices.text: Yes, let’s do it!
Maybe later, I’ll just observe.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: We’re not doing anything fancy. Just practical stuff, how students store food, what gets wasted, and what actually ends up helping places like the food bank. First, let’s sort leftover meals from the food bank. Which method ensures freshness and safety for donation?

choices.text: Store in containers and label with dates
Leave them uncovered in trays
Mix all leftovers together

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Yeah, that’s the better option. When food’s stored properly, it lasts longer, and less ends up in the bin. That’s fewer emissions, less waste, and fewer people needing emergency help.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Hmm...throwing away extra food wastes resources and misses the chance to help someone in need. But even this shows why we need awareness about food waste.

nodes.speaker: Matthew
nodes.text: Keeping it for yourself prevents others from benefiting, but it’s a good lesson on why sharing surplus food matters for the community and environment.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Hey! We have two mini activities: reducing food waste in your dorm or upcycling old items. You can try one or just observe. Which do you want?

choices.text: Reduce food waste in my dorm
Try upcycling old items
Maybe later, I’ll just watch.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Let’s reduce food waste! You found leftover meals in your dorm fridge. What’s the safest way to store them?

choices.text: Use containers and label with dates
Leave meals on the counter
Freeze all leftovers without sorting

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Excellent! Proper storage keeps food edible longer, reduces waste, and helps your campus community.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Leaving food exposed can spoil it quickly. You’ll see why safe storage matters for food security and climate impact.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Freezing helps preserve, but unsorted food may confuse donation or use. Learning to organize is key for responsible consumption.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Now let’s upcycle! You have empty bottles and old packaging. What’s the first thing to do?

choices.text: Make mini planters
Make reusable snack bags
Watch first and learn

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Perfect! Turning bottles into planters shows how waste can have a second life. Creative reuse reduces consumption and carbon footprint.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Great! Reusable snack bags cut single-use waste. Every small innovation adds up to big environmental impact.

nodes.speaker: Student Group
nodes.text: Watching is a good first step. Understanding the process helps you plan real actions to reduce waste and reuse creatively.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: You’ve engaged with the campus sustainability community. (SDG 12: Responsible Consumption, SDG 13: Climate Action)

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: As the day winds down, near the food bank, you notice someone sitting alone on a bench, looking at a care package from the food bank, the same one you helped pack earlier.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: A student you don't recognize yet. She seems tired but relieved, holding the food package carefully.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: A campus cat lounging nearby. APU is famous for its friendly cats.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: The cat meows at you. Probably hoping for some of those biscuits in the care package.

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: Oh! Hey! I honestly did not expect to run into you here. Uh, I...I just picked up my package.

nodes.speaker: Player
nodes.text: Yeah, that was my first time helping out. I didn't expect to...I mean, are you okay?

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: I'm okay now. My parents' kedai makan closed during COVID and never recovered. Scholarship covers tuition but not much else. Sometimes by end of month... it's hard.

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: I was so malu at first to come. But Abang Ibrahim said 'There's no shame in needing help, one day you'll help others too.' That changed how I see it.

choices.text: Sara, I had no idea you were going through this. I'm glad I could help.
Is there enough support? Maybe the uni should do more.
Ah, I did not expect this, maybe I should leave you some space.

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: Most people don't know. We look the same as everyone else kan? But seeing volunteers like you... it really means a lot. You make us feel less alone.

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: There are programs, but not everyone knows about them. That's why what you're doing, spreading awareness, is so important. Keep going, okay?

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: It's okay. I understand it's awkward. Just... remember that your help today really matters to people like me. Even if you don't see us.

nodes.speaker: Sara
nodes.text: Anyway, I should head back to my room. Thanks for listening. And thanks for volunteering today. It makes more difference than you know.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text: Watching Sara walk away with the care package, it hits you how easy it is to overlook people like her on campus. Not because they are invisible, but because they quietly carry their struggles alone.

nodes.speaker: system
nodes.text: End of Chapter 2: Taking Action. You've seen how student initiatives directly impact lives. The SDGs aren't just goals — they're about real people.
